"Brazil's Worker's Party (PT) has suffered a major blow after prosecutors charged vice presidential candidate Fernando Haddad with corruption." The Workers Party has vowed to keep Lula as their candidate, despite the Supreme Electoral Court's ruling barring him.   Today, the same court ruled that the Workers' Party must suspend the campaign programming that presents Lula as the party's presidential candidate.
A fine of 500,000 Brazilian reais (around 121,000 dollars) will be levied for every breach of the ruling. https://news.cgtn.com/news/3d3d514e3055544f79457a6333566d54/share_p.html
From 99 to 95% after reading comments by @Rahuul_Kumaar

Brazil’s top electoral court has ruled that jailed former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva cannot run as a candidate in the presidential election because of his corruption conviction. Judges voted against his running in October’s ballot by a majority of six votes to one in the seven-member court. Despite his jail sentence, PT voted to nominate Lula as its candidate last month. Lula reportedly chose Fernando Haddad, former mayor of São Paulo, to run for the PT should he be prevented from doing so.
https://www.inewsguyana.com/brazils-jailed-ex-leader-barred-from-presidential-race-by-electoral-court/ What happens in Lula’s absence? Still, the Workers’ Party is expected to decide on a new candidate to replace Lula – while its Federal Supreme Court request is pending. According to the electoral court decision, the party has 10 days from Saturday to nominate a new presidential candidate, with all signs pointing towards Fernando Haddad, Lula’s running mate and a former mayor of Sao Paulo. A party meeting is scheduled for Monday in the city of Curitiba, when Haddad’s candidacy is likely to be confirmed. If Lula’s Supreme Court appeal is successful, the Workers’ Party will still be able to put the former president back on the ballot. If not, the party will face the uphill task of transferring Lula’s votes to Haddad, a politician who is not instantly recognisable around the country and currently polls at just four percent. “It’s the only strategy available to them,” said Ribeiro. “But Lula’s popularity means there is a good chance it will be successful.” Indeed, Haddad can take heart in the fact that recent polls show 31 percent of the electorate would vote for any candidate endorsed by Lula, which would be more than enough to propel him into a potential second-round runoff with Jair Bolsonaro, a far-right candidate with the Social Liberty Party.
http://slinkingtowardretirement.com/?p=293312
Lula declared ineligible; workers party will hedge their bets.

Lula officially barred from running [1]. Will need to nominate someone else before 17 September, and all indications is that it will be someone from the same party. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/31/world/americas/lula-president-brazil.html
Supreme Electoral Court just barred Lula from running. No response yet from PT.

There is a very strong political will to apply the law as it is and not create any exception, much less in such a high profile case. The civil society and the judiciary power seems to be aligned here and on wanting the law to be applied, despite the high number of voting intentions for Lula. The legislative and the executive branches are surprisingly quiet and taking a neutral stand in the matter, mainly due to the unknown consequences of what backing each side might be. Given this scenario, I think Lula's candidacy will be revoke and the Worker's Party will have no option but to nominate a new candidate (and hope they will be able to surf on Lula's wave). I think there is still a 10% chance that the Worker's Party won't nominate any candidate and just not run for president, refusing the replace Lula's name in the election, in an attempt to stir up the validity of the elections.
It's very likely, but there's also the possibility of retiring their candidature if their vote intentions are bad.

Brazil’s left-leaning Workers’ party has announced that Fernando Haddad will become its presidential candidate if, as expected, jailed ex-president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva is barred from running in the October election. The announcement by party chairwoman Gleisi Hoffman immediately propels the former São Paulo mayor, a candidate who has barely registered in the polls thus far, to one of the leading contenders to become Brazil’s next president.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/aug/06/brazil-workers-party-backup-jailed-presidential-candidate

On July12, the Supreme Federal Tribunal turned down 143 Habeas Corpus requests filed with the intention of getting Lula out of jail. And the judicial system doesnt respond well to pressure. Here is link.  https://politica.estadao.com.br/blogs/fausto-macedo/o-habeas-padronizado-parag-lula-negado-por-laurita/   There is a lot of turmoil in the justice system at all levels and there will be more as positioning for October elections plays out. I have revised my forecast only because some conditional probablities are starting to show up in Brazil media that don't reach many in this community in US, EU, which could help increase the probability of a 'political solution' that could be negotiated and allow Lula to run.  Then too, one might recast this question incorporating the possibility that the PT (Workers Party) will nominate Lula, but for the purpose of having the nomination-candidacy ruled illegal. There is nobody, but nobody in the PT who would want to run as a stand in for Lula. It would be an embarassment to the already tarnished pride of the party, and offer no upside to the career of whoever would be enough of a schlamiel to go for it.

Don't know much about Brazil. Just Havaianas, Rio, soccer, copiaba (is that the drink?, misspelled it anyways I think and there is that copiabera or something. Oh and that martial arts dancing thingy copiera?). Oh and Carnival! Senna, Copacabana, Ipanema. Fun! Pele. Neymar rolling around everywhere and spending 14 minutes on the ground at the 2018 World Cup. Hmm. Can Neymar SCUBA dive too?  And Amazon and cutting it all down, logging and farming. They export lots of beef!  And they speak Portuguese, not 'Brazilian' (that's another thing) or Spanish. Which comes in handy in Lisbon. And some island around Asia, not sure if it is still spoken in Timor Leste. What else? Oh and someone that went there didn't like it and said they're real picky about who can walk on the beach in skimpy outfits. Probably not true but seems like a cool place to visit.  And they have lots of slums and crime, and the elite have helicopters to hop from building to building, which is pretty awesome, no traffic or carjacking risk.  Oh and 60 or so percent of 18 to 34 year olds want to leave.  So I really shouldn't be in this q, but what the heck, it's fun and might learn something.  It seems Lula fans are sticking loyal. And a chance of freedom, so moving down from 99 to 90.

A judge ordered that Lula be freed three times but was overruled, as Brazilians compared the drama to a World Cup shootout https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jul/09/brazil-lula-supporters-hope-release-is-near-after-weekend-of-legal-drama
The worker's party is too tied to Lula at this point to get organized internally and submit a different candidate. The recent effort to free him shows they are mostly focused on making Lula a martyr.
there is a reasonable chance that he'll be nominated  https://therealnews.com/stories/the-near-release-of-brazils-lula

Not only the Supreme Court has turned down the appeal, but also Palocci cooperating with prosecutors against Lula.
PoT and WoC at 80 down from 99.
Legal maneuvering by his lawyers not working in Lula's favor.

The Workers Party (PT) is maintaining the candidacy of Lula for now as a way to maintain control of the narrative that the former president has been wrongly condemned and removing the candidacy now would send a message that they accept this reality, a kind of move that the party has shown to avoid. In that sense, I believe that they will try to hold this narrative until the very close to August when the official election starts and the candidates are officially announced, or even close to the elections itself, and they would likely try to either invite Ciro Gomes to be their official candidate or launch a strong man in the party. 
Briefly, I think it's very unlikely (10 to 15% chance) that the PT will go on in their first elections without a valid candidate as they know that the Electoral Court will not accept Lula's candidacy or even election as it would represent a very negative decision with strong repercussion about the weakness of the institution.
Signs of a coalition are growing. But they might have to give up governor candidacies to get out of the way of other parties.

Having considered the 'not Lula' option, on further review PT has no candidate who is what in Brazilian Portuguese can be considered a 'presidenciavel'...  someone who is 'presidential timber' as the folks at The Cook Political Report might say. The most recent poll released by the 'most trusted' DataFolha shop shows 30% of those who responded would absolutely vote for the candidate Lula tells them to vote for and another 17% percent indicated that they 'might' consider voting for whoever Lula says they should elect.  Still 51% of the responders think that Lula should not be elgible to run because he is in jail, and in violation of the law.  Here is link http://www.jb.com.br/pais/noticias/2018/06/10/datafolha-lula-tem-30-bolsonaro-17-marina-10/       Lula is way out in front of neo-Integralist and ex Army captain Jair Bolsonaro who is trying to capitalize on his military background as a mere company grade officer, and perennial gadfly Marina Silva with her ties to the Brazilian and US Assemblies of God churches...  Forget notions of martyrdom. Lula's brand, or re-brand still has a lot of 'value added.'
Reducing from 88% as they seem to be sticking with the Lula plan. It seems like a hopeless plan, but god help me, Brazilian politics isn't exactly filled with rational actors.

The Worker's Party is now promoting a "National Act" for launching the candidacy to the presidency on 8 June with Lula as their candidate... Asking people to organize caravans all over the country on that day.  According to TeleSur, the PT will formalize Lula's candidacy on August 15.  A "clean criminal record" is a pre-requisite for election candidates since 2010 but there have been exceptions to this law, although not at a federal level. Lula is technically in prison while he awaits his pending appeal.  That may be a technicality, but in the current political environment and the people controlling the courts, Lula has zero to none chances to get out.  If the PT does officially register Lula to run by the August 15 deadline, the Superior Electoral Court will review the candidacy application and likely rule he is ineligible under the new "clean slate" law.  Meanwhile, the PT has said there is a clause in the clean slate law that may benefit Lula but that, too, would require political will. ( http://www.valor.com.br/politica/5532797/pt-ve-brecha-na-lei-da-ficha-limpa-para-lula-disputar-presidencia )  As per Bloomberg, here's another possible scenario:   "Lula’s lawyers could request an injunction by the Superior Court of Justice, which would look at any abuse of process, or by the Supreme Court, which would examine the possible violation of constitutional principles, potentially allowing Lula to run. If the Superior Electoral Court bans Lula from running after the August 15 deadline date for registering candidates, he could still appeal that decision at the Supreme Court."
Pretty soon they will want to have an actual candidate, assuming they are not wildly out of touch with reality.  But of course one never knows about that.

Lula may lead in the polls and the Northeast population would probably vote for him even if he were dead. However, having lost his second appeal, he is ineligible. I don’t understand why, but I have read that a final decision will be made on September 17 when the Superior Electoral Tribunal will make a final ruling. It doesn’t matter, he can’t run. I have a small probability that Christ the Redeemer descends from the mountain in Rio and anoints him king, but I’m not holding my breath. He offered to let another candidate run, but PT leadership declined. This is a useless show of unity that will collapse. However, keeping Lula as a candidate is a way to maximize the eventual transfer of his political capital to His successor. The current strategy is a good strategy. Voting is mandatory, so the coattails impact of a PT candidate is less important than in other parliamentary democracies. However, the incentive remains to maintain a high PT profile until his usefulness diminishes. Then he will be abandoned and his new friends will be prison folk. He has already dropped a bit in the polls. Since his support in the northeast is so high, one would expect another PT candidate to carry some of the vote. It would foolish to squander this party support. Recent law changes make it harder for candidates to switch parties.
Not really a good statistical chance time == notLongEnough

TeleSur reporting today that Lula da Silva still leads in the polls a week before he registers officially to run.  At the end of April, Lula had said the Workers Party, all on the same week the party released Lula's proposed government program.  Within days, both Lula and Senator Gleisi Hoffmann, who is leading the Workers Party, and who served as chief of staff under Dilma Rousseff, were hit with new corruption charges accusing them of having access to a $40 million slush fund in 2010 funded by Odebrecht in exchange for government decisions that would benefit the company. (As reported by Reuters) Hoffmann says there is no material evidence justifying the charges made against Lula and that he leads the polls by a wide margin with twice the support of his nearest competitor, 6 times the support of any other candidate, and 30 times the support of Guilherme Boulos, who is being referred to "as the heir apparent for the Brazilian left."   The latest is that the Workers Party insists that Lula will run for the Presidency from behind bars if necessary, "as Bobby Sands did for British Parliament from the Maze penitentiary in 1981."  Will he be allowed to? Not likely. Meanwhile, the UN launched a probe into "the violation of Lula's rights" this week.    From what it looks like at this point, the Workers Party is fighting it, trying to stick to its guns to run Lula from prison even if to make a statement.  That may be their biggest weapon at the moment to influence public opinion.  They don't seem to have much leverage in the courts.  And if the corruption scandal and accusations continue to mire Lula and the party leaders, (Hoffman and her husband facing charges; Lula's right hand, the former minister, José Dirceu, was recently sentenced to 30 years in prison for corruption, found guilty of receiving bribes from Petrobras, the same crime that led to former president Lula) they're fighting not for a victory but for any type of relevance and survival.  If the Workers Party's leaders deem the probabilities of winning the general election in October are that of unlikely victory, they might as well make a stronger statement running Lula in prison. Lula's popularity is not likely to transfer to another candidate the WP runs.  Watching what will happen in the next few weeks as Brazilian authorities will most likely disqualify Lula from being on the ballot.
As one Minister at the Supreme Federal Tribunal said quoted on the G1, it is a question of mathematics. Pretty Boy Haddad has been indicted. Ditto Jaques Wagner. You can't relive the past.
This seems likely unless the situation in the country changes drastically in the next few months.

Brazilian law allows a party to change nominations 20 days before the election.

3.  Pick an ally politician - who would work to get lula out of jail. hundeds of billion dollars of assetts.

Lula is condemtent and in jail unless lawmakers change law probabilities that luls became candidate are 0
Lowering my forecast because considering the odd of PT not nominating any candidate.
Lula has thrown the kitchen sink and everything else at it but still failed to get past the courts.
Lula is now in jail, the'll find someone who can fit.
It will be a last moment nomination, although he might have the pull to make all charges go away.
Lula remains the front runner for the workers party but it seems likely that another candidate who isn't in prison will end up consolidating power in the party.
He's had too long to prove his innocence and the Brazilian people are fed up.

Lula is de facto out of run still the party can select him to be a candidate and trigger a series of legal battles, that is a losing strategy for the PT, thus my appeal to rational thinking and get someone else in this ballot!

Haddad, 55, the former mayor of Brazil’s largest city, Sao Paulo, is the Workers Party’s “Plan B” in the likely case that Lula cannot run. Sources in the party said Lula has privately discussed the need for Haddad to start preparing to run, even while the party plans to stick to their founder’s candidacy.
http://en.mercopress.com/2018/04/19/lula-s-party-preparing-plan-b-a-united-left-front-for-october-elections

I am brazilian and follow closely the political and electoral process here. The electoral law prohibits any person convicted by an appelation court to run for any positions. BUT, anyone can present its name for the elections and the electoral court must validate the candidacy, and this process can take several months, so there is the possibility that he is the candidate during elections day but later next year find his candidacy nulled. So, yes, in practical terms, he can be the candidate, even from jail. The important question is: will he and his party stress the electoral, consitutional and, in general, the legal system and institutions to this point, increasing the sense of political instability and uncertainty?

I don't really know but consensus at 98% seems overconfident. There are a ton of ways this could resolve as "no". The whole process could drag on and on past Oct, with PT maybe hoping for popular pressure to allow Lula to run. Or they could decide to join a coalition and support a candidate from a different party, thus not nominating one of their own. I don't think they have one with really good national name recognition, certainly not the kind Marina Silva has. Brazilian politics is all about coalitions. Btw the accent in Inàcio is facing the wrong way, it should be Inácio.
The poor are not onboard with the rich  trying to break their party

Workers Party senator is calling for the party not to run any candidate in the elections. Meanwhile, all 60 Workers Party members in congress changed their named to Lula in solidarity with the jailed former president. 
Also this week, Lula's legal team submitted another legal recourse to the country's supreme court asking immediate release of the former president.  Looks like check mate for Lula, Dilma and WP for now. But Lula is adamant to stay on the ballot and his party seems to be behind him.  The Washington Post reports he is still leading presidential polls, will remain in jail until all appeal are exhausted.  "Da Silva has been found guilty in one case, which is on appeal, and is a defendant in five other corruption-related cases, but that does not immediately disqualify him from being a presidential candidate. Until July 20, the former president and all others seeking the presidency are technically only potential candidates; Aug. 15 is the last date that candidacies can be made official. The Brazilian Supreme Electoral Court has until Sept. 17 to analyze all candidacy bids."
